skipstagemodule.label: Skip the introduction, I'm ready to request bikeshare parking!

htmlmodule.label: hub_information
htmlmodule.content:
What is a hub?

Hubs are preferred parking areas for bikeshare bicycles. These are places where bikeshare users are encouraged to park when ending a trip and where Lime relocates bikes to provide convenient and reliable service.

Hubs are marked with white boxes and symbols painted on sidewalks or street shoulders, and they are shown in operators' mobile apps.

htmlmodule.label: hub_location_information
htmlmodule.content:
Where should hubs go?

Anywhere you want to go by bike! We're aiming to provide a network of conveniently located hubs citywide. Suggest locations in your neighborhood, outside your workplace, at your local park, near your favorite café, restaurants, and shops.

If you don't see a suggested location in the half-mile (solid) or quarter-mile (dashed) grid squares near places you want to use bikeshare, that is an especially good place to suggest one.

htmlmodule.label: existing_hubs_information
htmlmodule.content:
Existing hubs

Hubs have already been installed at 50 locations across the city, including in Downtown, Crossroads, Factoria, and near major bus stops and community spaces.

Toggle these with the Existing Hubs layer.

htmlmodule.label: bicycle_network_information
htmlmodule.content:
Bicycle network

Not sure where to ride? Toggle the Bike Network layer to see where bike lanes and offstreet paths are near where you want to go.

htmlmodule.label: access_to_transit_information
htmlmodule.content:
Access to transit

Bikeshare can help people get to and from transit more quickly. By locating hubs within walking distance of frequent bus routes, buses and bikeshare can both be more useful.

This map shows the quarter-mile walkshed around Bellevue's frequent transit network.

htmlmodule.label: submission_info
htmlmodule.content:
What do you think?

Drag and zoom the map to let us know where you think we should add a bikeshare hub! Fill out the form below to give us some more information about your suggestion:

textfield.label: Title:
textfield.placeholder: Enter title...

htmlmodule.label: location_information_header
htmlmodule.content: 1. Your property

htmlmodule.label: location_why
htmlmodule.content:
At the end of this survey you will be able to hide your contact information and location information or voluntarily choose to make it public for the VSP report.

If you own multiple properties, please report on all your properties by watershed. If they are all within the same watershed, we would only need one pin. If you have property in multiple watersheds please complete this survey by watershed and place a pin in each watershed.

htmlmodule.label: drag_map_info
htmlmodule.content: Please drag and zoom the map to center pin on your property. If you own/lease multiple properties you'll only need to place one pin, but if you have other properties in other watersheds we would request a separate survey in each watershed and report acres by watershed.

addressfield.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

radiofield.prompt: Of the eight watersheds on the map, which unit primarily represents your farm or ranch?  All reporting for VSP will be at the watershed scale level. Complete multiple surveys for areas that are distinctly different.

htmlmodule.label: additional_info
htmlmodule.content:
Thank you for taking the time to voluntarily report your stewardship practices.

This page will determine how your information is shared. We will report all practices at the watershed scale, but if you are interested in having your project showcased you can give us permission below. Either way, we will be using your stewardship practice to capture how agriculture is protecting and/or restoring critical areas and maintaining the viability of agriculture.

htmlmodule.label: large_fires_information
htmlmodule.content:
Kittitas County is in the heart of fire-prone country. 36 large fires have burned here since 1973.

Click on fires on the map to learn more about them, and use the slider in the lower left to explore the changing wildfire risk in central Washington.

Large wildfires in Kittitas County
Large wildfires elsewhere in Washington
36Large wildfires started since 1973227,533Total acres burned

radiofield.prompt: On your land, which forest type is predominant? (See below for descriptions and images of forest types.)

htmlmodule.label: forest_type_information
htmlmodule.content:
Subalpine: Subalpine fir generally occupies colder, higher elevation mountain forests. Fires are typically stand-replacing events at approximately 200-year or greater intervals. When wildfire occurs, this forest is more susceptible to high intensity crown fires.

Fire return interval200+ years

Moist Mix Conifer: Forests of grand fir, white fir, and Douglas-fir with an average fire return interval of 45-100 years. When wildfire occurs in this forest type it can vary from medium to high severity.

Fire return interval45-100 years

Dry Forest: A forest dominated by ponderosa pine, with understory conifers like Douglas Fir and Grand Fir. Lack of wildfire can result in dense stands highly susceptible to medium to high intensity fires. The wildfire return intervals are 15-25 years.

Fire return interval15-25 years

Ponderosa Pine: Straddles the line between rangelands and forest with an overstory of ponderosa pine trees and an understory of shrubs, grasses, and forbs. Wildfires were historically common in this forest type, with return intervals of 8-15 years.

Fire return interval8-15 years

Non-forest Rangeland: Rangeland (shrub steppe with sagebrush and grasses) with fire intervals of 5-15 years. When wildfire occurs in this land cover type, the severity is dependent on the vegetation density and weather (wind-driven).

Fire return interval5-15 years

htmlmodule.label: fire_risk_information
htmlmodule.content:
Wildfire risk varies throughout Kittitas County. The probability of wildfire is based on historical fires, vegetation and public safety.

Severe risk

Low risk

This map shows general wildfire probability. Wind-blown embers generated during wildfires are the single biggest hazard wildfires pose to homes. Look at the risk level not just where your home is located but at least in a one mile radius to better understand your risk from these burning pieces of airborne wood and/or vegetation.

This map also shows large wildfires and individual wildfire start sites from the last several years. Click on a start site to learn more about it.

addressfield.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

htmlmodule.label: fire_resources_information
htmlmodule.content:
Kittitas County has numerous fire resources you should be aware of, including fire districts and Firewise USA communities.

Search for your address above (or zoom and scroll the map) to explore resources in your area.

If you know your tax parcel number but not your address, go to https://gis.co.kittitas.wa.us/compas/default.aspx and enter your parcel number to find more information including the "situs" address.

If your property resides in a fire district, it does not guarantee that the fire district or fire department will be able to defend your property during a wildfire event.

htmlmodule.label: fire_resiliency_header
htmlmodule.content: Your Path to Wildfire Resilience

htmlmodule.label: fire_resiliency_information
htmlmodule.content:
Be resilient! As a landowner in a fire environment, what you do (and don't do!) on your property matters.

Tell us a bit about your property and practices, and we'll send you a customized report with fire resiliency resources and other information.

We'll ask about your fire resiliency practices in three zones around your property:

  • Immediate Zone: 0 - 5 feet from house
  • Intermediate Zone: 5 - 30 feet from house
  • Extended Zone: 30 - 100 feet from house

htmlmodule.label: immediate_zone_header
htmlmodule.content: Immediate Zone Actions

htmlmodule.label: immediate_zone_information
htmlmodule.content: The immediate zone extends to 5 feet from your house. This zone is the most vulnerable to embers. Start here with your fire resiliency efforts.

radiofield.label: Clean roofs and gutters
radiofield.prompt: I clean roofs and gutters of dead leaves, debris and pine needles that could catch embers and I keep my roof in good repair.

radiofield.label: Replace or repair loose shingles
radiofield.prompt: I replace or repair any loose or missing shingles or roof tiles to prevent ember penetration

radiofield.label: Reduce embers
radiofield.prompt: I've installed 1/8 inch metal mesh screening on foundation vents and/or exterior attic vents.

radiofield.label: Clean debris from attic vents
radiofield.prompt: I clean debris from exterior attic vents and install 1/8 inch metal mesh screening to reduce embers

radiofield.label: Repair or replace window screens
radiofield.prompt: I've screened in areas below patios and decks with wire mesh to prevent debris and combustible materials from accumulating

radiofield.label: Move flammable material
radiofield.prompt: I've moved any flammable material away from wall exteriors--mulch, flammable plants, leaves and needles, firewood piles--anything that can burn as well as anything stored underneath decks or porches.

htmlmodule.label: intermediate_zone_header
htmlmodule.content: Intermediate Zone Actions

htmlmodule.label: intermediate_zone_information
htmlmodule.content: The intermediate zone extends between 5 and 30 feet from your house. In this zone, using careful landscaping or hardscaping techniques to create fuel breaks can help decrease fire behavior.

radiofield.label: Clear vegetation from propane tanks
radiofield.prompt: I clear vegetation from under and in a 5-foot perimeter around my propane tank

radiofield.label: Create fuel breaks
radiofield.prompt: I've created fuel breaks with driveways, walkways/paths, patios, and decks

radiofield.label: Keep lawns mowed to four inches
radiofield.prompt: I keep lawns and native grasses mowed to a height of four inches

radiofield.label: Remove ladder fuels
radiofield.prompt: I prune tree limbs so the lowest branches are 6 to 10 feet above the ground to help reduce the chance of fire getting into the crowns of the trees

radiofield.label: Space trees to eighteen feet
radiofield.prompt: I space trees to have a minimum of 18 feet between crowns, with the distance increasing with the percentage of slope

radiofield.label: Keep tree canopy ten feet from structures
radiofield.prompt: I ensure that mature tree canopy is no closer than ten feet to the edge of any structures on my property

radiofield.label: Break up continuity of vegetation
radiofield.prompt: I ensure that trees and shrubs in the intermediate zone are limited to small clusters of a few each to break up the continuity of vegetation

htmlmodule.label: extended_zone_header
htmlmodule.content: Extended Zone Actions

htmlmodule.label: extended_zone_information
htmlmodule.content: From your home, this zone extends out 30 to 100 feet or even 200 feet if on a slope. The goal here is not to eliminate fire but to interrupt fire's path and keep flames smaller and on the ground.

radiofield.label: Dispose of ground debris
radiofield.prompt: I dispose of heavy accumulations of ground litter and debris

radiofield.label: Remove dead plant material
radiofield.prompt: I regularly remove dead plant and tree material

radiofield.label: Remove small conifers between mature trees
radiofield.prompt: I remove small conifers growing between mature trees

radiofield.label: Remove adjacent outbuilding vegetation
radiofield.prompt: I remove vegetation adjacent to storage sheds or other outbuildings

radiofield.label: Space canopy tops 30 to 60 feet from the house
radiofield.prompt: I ensure that trees 30 to 60 feet from the home have at least 12 feet between canopy tops

radiofield.label: Space canopy tops 60 to 100 feet from the house
radiofield.prompt: I ensure that trees 60 to 100 feet from the home have at least 6 feet between the canopy tops

htmlmodule.label: emergency_evacuation_header
htmlmodule.content: Emergency and Evacuation Planning

radiofield.label: Evacuation plan
radiofield.prompt: I have an evacuation plan that includes escape routes (preferably 2), a designated family meeting location, and a communication plan

radiofield.label: Food and water
radiofield.prompt: I have an emergency kit prepared with water, food, clothes, flashlight, first aid kit, etc.

radiofield.label: Copies of documents
radiofield.prompt: I have my important family documents, bank and credit card information, identification, prescriptions, etc. in one location easily accessible during an evacuation

radiofield.label: Evacuation plan
radiofield.prompt: I have an evacuation plan for my pets, large animals or livestock

radiofield.label: Food and water
radiofield.prompt: I've signed up for the emergency notification system through the Kittitas County Sheriff's Office or I know where to go for official information
How do you feel about your answers to list of tasks in the area around your home?

options.label: I'm very confident that I've taken the actions that reduce my risk in a wildfire
I'm somewhat confident that I've taken the actions that reduce my risk in a wildfire
I've completed some of these actions, but have many left to do
I'm overwhelmed by the list of actions and concerned about my property and my neighborhood

checkboxfield.prompt: If you have not completed some of the tasks, why not? (check all that apply)

options.label: I didn't know they were important to reducing my risk
I am not able to do the work myself
I can't afford to have the work done

checkboxfield.prompt: There are people and programs here to help you with assessing your property, determining next steps and securing grants to help with the financial burden of completing work. Just let us know what you need

options.label: I'm interested in technical advice on what my home and property need
I'm interested in learning more about available financial assistance

htmlmodule.label: wetlands_information
htmlmodule.content:
Description

Wetland areas are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater.

Appearance on map

radiofield.prompt: Are there any wetlands?

htmlmodule.label: wetlands_disclaimer
htmlmodule.content: The wetlands data is supplied by US Fish & Wildlife Service through their National Wetlands Inventory. Their maps are prepared from the analysis of high altitude imagery. Wetlands are identified based on vegetation, visible hydrology and geography. A margin of error is inherent in the use of imagery. Landowners interested in an on-the-ground assessment to confirm the presence of these mapped wetlands for the purposes of the Voluntary Stewardship Program are encouraged to contact the KCCD.

htmlmodule.label: frequently_flooded_information
htmlmodule.content:
Description

Frequently flooded areas are subject to a 1% or greater chance of flooding every year.

Appearance on map

radiofield.prompt: Are there any frequently flooded areas?

htmlmodule.label: frequently_flooded_disclaimer
htmlmodule.content: Frequently flood areas on this map are a combination of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) flood insurance rate map (FIRM) designated 100- year floodplain and floodway.

htmlmodule.label: geologic_hazard_information
htmlmodule.content:

radiofield.prompt: Are there any severe geologic hazard areas?

htmlmodule.label: geologic_hazard_disclaimer
htmlmodule.content: The data displayed on this map includes soil types with a slope of 25% or greater as an approximation of areas where geologic hazards may exist. For more detailed information on geologic hazards contact the KCCD.

htmlmodule.label: critical_aquifer_information
htmlmodule.content:
Description

Critical aquifer recharge areas have a critical effect on aquifers used for potable water.

Appearance on map

radiofield.prompt: Are there any critical aquifer recharge areas?

htmlmodule.label: critical_aquifer_disclaimer
htmlmodule.content: Kittitas County does not currently have a designated critical aquifer recharge area, however wellhead protection for public water systems is an important component of the larger effort to protect aquifers used for potable water. The data shown here are the Group A and Group B wells with a 600 foot to 10,000 foot buffer depending on the number of connections allowed. For additional information on Critical Aquifer Recharge Areas, contact the KCCD.

htmlmodule.label: fish_wildlife_habitat_information
htmlmodule.content:
Description

Fish & wildlife habitats are managed to maintain populations of fish and wildlife. Zoom the map to explore which species live in your area.

Appearance on map
Priority habitats: areas with unique or significant value to many species
Fish-bearing waterways: creeks and rivers that are priority habitats for Summer Steelhead, Spring Chinook, Coho, Dolly Varden/Bull Trout, Westslope Cutthroat, Mountain Sucker, or Rainbow Trout

radiofield.prompt: Are there any fish & wildlife conservation areas?

htmlmodule.label: fish_wildlife_habitat_disclaimer
htmlmodule.content: The Fish and Wildlife Conservation areas are provided by the Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife's Priority Habitats and Species (PHS) Program. For more specific information on habitats or species on or near your property, contact the KCCD.

htmlmodule.label: additional_info
htmlmodule.content:
Thank you for taking the time to voluntarily report your stewardship practices.

This page will determine how your information is shared. We will report all practices at the watershed scale, but if you are interested in having your project showcased you can give us permission below. Either way, we will be using your stewardship practice to capture how agriculture is protecting and/or restoring critical areas and maintaining the viability of agriculture.

htmlmodule.label: location_information_header
htmlmodule.content: 1. Your property

htmlmodule.label: location_why
htmlmodule.content:
At the end of this survey you will be able to hide your contact information and location information or voluntarily choose to make it public for the VSP report.

If you own multiple properties within one of the Watershed Analysis Unit we only need one report from you, since we will be reporting Stewardship Actions by Watershed Analysis Units. If you have additional properties in another Watershed Analysis Unit please submit a second report so that we can capture Stewardship Actions by the correct Watershed Analysis Unit.

htmlmodule.label: drag_map_info
htmlmodule.content: If you own multiple properties within one of the Watershed Analysis Unit we only need one report from you, since we will be reporting Stewardship Actions by Watershed Analysis Units. If you have additional properties in another Watershed Analysis Unit please submit a second report so that we can captured Stewardship Actions by the correct Watershed Analysis Unit.

addressfield.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

radiofield.prompt: Of the three VSP watershed analysis units on map (Rock, Palouse, or Snake), which unit primarily represents your farm or ranch?  All reporting for VSP will be at the watershed analysis unit scale level. Complete multiple surveys for areas that are distinctly different.

info_modal.content: A rain garden is an area that is dug out, lined with a special soil mix, and planted with the intent of infiltrating runoff from your house, driveway, or other hardened surfaces.

datefield.prompt: Approximately when did you last complete this action?
Approximately when did you last complete this action?

info_modal.content: A rain bed combines a rain barrel system with a raised garden bed. A special gutter in the raised bed spreads water from the barrels over the garden for easy watering. Excess water from the barrels infiltrates through the bed and is dispersed over the surrounding yard where it is filtered and infiltrated.

datefield.prompt: Approximately when did you last complete this action?

datefield.prompt: Approximately when did you last complete this action?
Approximately when did you last complete this action?

textareafield.prompt: Please comment or elaborate here:

textfield.prompt: Enter a headline that describes your experiences
textfield.placeholder: Example - Protecting Catherine Creek for fish, Turning my yard into a wildlife haven, etc

filefield.label: 📷 Add an Image
filefield.prompt: Please share an image of your work

textfield.prompt: Your Email (important in case we need to follow up)
textfield.placeholder: Optional. Your email will never be shared

textareafield.prompt: Anything else you'd like us to know?

htmlmodule.label: location_information_header
htmlmodule.content: 1. Your property

htmlmodule.label: location_why
htmlmodule.content: At the end of this survey you will be able to hide your contact information and location information or voluntarily choose to make it public for the VSP report.

htmlmodule.label: drag_map_info
htmlmodule.content: Please drag and zoom the map to center the pin on your property.

addressfield.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

htmlmodule.label: practice_types_header
htmlmodule.content: 2. Land Use

checkboxfield.prompt: Which of the following uses apply to your land? (Check all that apply)

htmlmodule.label: practice_types_questions
htmlmodule.content: Questions? Call Doug Phelps at 509-535-7274 x240

radiofield.prompt: No till
radiofield.label: No till

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 329

No till consists of one pass seed and fertilizer placement.

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you practice no till?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been practicing no till?
Conventional till
radiofield.label: Conventional till

info_modal.content: This practice consists of multiple tillage passes with soil inversion and seed bed preparation.

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you use conventional till techniques?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been using conventional till techniques?
Reduced till
radiofield.label: Reduced till

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 345

This practice consists of seed and fertilizer placement while allowing the majority of crop residue and stubble to remain on the ground.

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you use reduced till techniques?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been using reduced till techniques?
Do you conduct soil tests?
radiofield.label: Soil tests

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 590

Soil tests monitor, at a minimum, organic matter, phosphorus (P), potassium (K), and pH every four years.

radiofield.prompt: Do you zone and map your fields based off of soil tests?

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you conduct soil tests?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been conducting soil tests?
How do you fertilize your field?
radiofield.label: Field fertilization

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 590 590

Crops can be fertilized with various products and application methods.

checkboxfield.prompt: Choose all fertilization types that apply:

radiofield.prompt: Do you base your synthetic fertilizing off of a yield map?
Have you developed a zone map for synthetic fertilization?

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you use synthetic fertilizer?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been fertilizing your fields synthetically?

checkboxfield.prompt: Choose all fertilization types that apply:

radiofield.prompt: Do you base your organic fertilizing off of a yield map?
Have you developed a zone map for organic fertilization?

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you use organic fertilizer?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been fertilizing your fields organically?
Do you have buffers on your waterways?
radiofield.label: Buffers

info_modal.content:
NRCS codes: 342, 391, 580, 386, 393

Vegetated buffers reduce erosion and provide wildlife habitat.

checkboxfield.prompt: Which types of buffers do you have on your waterways?

radiofield.prompt: Do you have any other types of buffers on your property?

textareafield.prompt: Please describe your other buffer(s)

numberfield.prompt: How many feet of buffers have you installed?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been installing buffers?
Did you install these buffers through a program?
Grassed waterways
radiofield.label: Grassed waterways

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 412

A grassed waterway is a shaped or graded channel that is established with suitable vegetation to convey surface water at a non-erosive velocity using a broad and shallow cross section to a stable outlet.

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you use grassed waterways?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been using grassed waterways?
I participate in the commodity buffer program
radiofield.label: Commodity buffer program

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been participating in the commodity buffer program?
Do you have any wildlife habitat enhancements on your property?
radiofield.label: Wildlife habitat enhancements

info_modal.content:
NRCS codes: 395, 420, 644, 645

A corridor of trees and/or shrubs planted adjacent to a river, stream, wetland or water body. The planting is of sufficient width and up-gradient and near the water body to insure adequate functioning for the desired purpose.

numberfield.prompt: How many acres of wildlife habitat have you enhanced?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been enhancing wildlife habitat?

textareafield.prompt: Please describe your wildlife habitat enhancements:

htmlmodule.label: agriculture_questions
htmlmodule.content: Questions? Call Doug Phelps at 509-535-7274 x240

htmlmodule.label: livestock_header
htmlmodule.content: 4. Livestock

radiofield.prompt: Stream crossings
radiofield.label: Stream crossings

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 578

A stream crossing is a stabilized area or structure constructed across a stream to provide a travel way for people, livestock, equipment, or vehicles.

checkboxfield.prompt: Which types of crossings have you installed? (Check all that apply)

numberfield.prompt: How many stream crossings have you installed?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been installing stream crossings?
Fencing
radiofield.label: Fencing

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 382

There are many different purposes for and types of fences. Generally, fences shall be appropriately planned, designed, and installed to control animals, vehicles, or people.

numberfield.prompt: How many feet of fencing have you installed?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been installing and maintaining fencing?
Mud and manure management
radiofield.label: Mud and manure management

info_modal.content:
NRCS code: 561

Heavy Use Area Protection is used to stabilize a ground surface that is frequently and intensively used by people, animals, or vehicles.

numberfield.prompt: On how many acres do you practice mud and manure management?

checkboxfield.prompt: Which types of mud and manure management do you practice? (Check all that apply)

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been practicing mud and manure management?
Off creek stock watering
radiofield.label: Off creek stock watering

info_modal.content:
NRCS codes: 516, 533, 614, 561, 642

A means of providing drinking water to livestock away from streams and wetlands.

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been maintaining off creek stock watering systems?

htmlmodule.label: livestock_questions
htmlmodule.content: Questions? Call Doug Phelps at 509-535-7274 x240

htmlmodule.label: forest_header
htmlmodule.content: 5. Forestry

radiofield.prompt: Do you have a forest you are managing?
radiofield.label: Forest management

info_modal.content:
NRCS codes: 612, 660, 666

Management practices can include planning, planting, pruning and the removal of undesirable vegetation.

textareafield.prompt: Please describe:

numberfield.prompt: How many acres is your timber stand?

radiofield.prompt: For how long have you been managing your forest?
Do you have any type of forest management plan?
Are you actively managing your forest as prescribed by your plan?

htmlmodule.label: forest_questions
htmlmodule.content: Questions? Call Doug Phelps at 509-535-7274 x240

htmlmodule.content: 6. Almost completed
